    Re-encoding Greek characters from â€˜EDHâ€™ dataset

    Antonio Rivero Ostoic

    CEDHAR, Aarhus University

    jaro@cas.au.dk

    12 March 2021

    Encoding.Rmd

    Preliminaries

    "sdam" is an R package that provides tools for performing analyses within Social Dynamics and complexity in the Ancient Mediterranean SDAM, which is a research group based at Aarhus University. It allows accessing and manipulating data from the Epigraphic Database Heidelberg API, performing HTTP requests, visualizing interval time events, compute probabilities of existence of archaeological assemblages and artifacts, and produce similarity matrices by simple matching between these objects.

    # install RC version from Github
devtools::install_github("sdam-au/sdam")
# or the beta version
devtools::install_github("mplex/cedhar", subdir="pkg/sdam")
    # load package and check version
library("sdam")
packageVersion("sdam")
    [1] '0.9.3'

    EDH people

    EDH is a dataset that contains the texts of Latin and Latin-Greek inscriptions of the Roman Empire, which have been retrieved from the Epigraphic Database Heidelberg API repository through routines get.edh() and get.edhw().

    The following sample is from the EDH dataset where we extract variables with function edhw() and record this data in object edhdf.

    # people nomen tribus dates provs
edhdf <- edhw(vars=c("people","not_before","not_after","province_label"), select=c("tribus","nomen"))

    By default, edhw() produces a data frame that in this case has 6 variables:

    # object list with its structure
ls.str(edhdf)
    id :  chr [1:141507] "HD000001" "HD000001" "HD000001" "HD000002" "HD000003" "HD000004" "HD000004" ...
nomen :  chr [1:141507] "Nonia" "Iulius" "Iulius" "Sextius" "Mummius+" NA "Porcius" "[---]" "[---]" ...
not_after :  chr [1:141507] "0130" "0130" "0130" "0200" "0170" "0200" "0200" "0200" "0200" "0200" "0150" ...
not_before :  chr [1:141507] "0071" "0071" "0071" "0051" "0131" "0151" "0151" "0001" "0001" "0001" "0071" ...
province_label :  chr [1:141507] "Latium et Campania (Regio I)" "Latium et Campania (Regio I)" ...
tribus :  chr [1:141507] NA NA NA NA "Galeria+" NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA ...

    Peopleâ€™s nomen per province

    "sdam" comes with a suite of datasets where "rp" containes Roman province names and acronyms as in EDH, and we use this data to organize the extracted information per Roman province in edhdf. In the following example, each "rp" name defines a component of list edhs by applying the province argument of function edhw().

    # load province names and acronyms as in EDH
data("rp")
# retrieve data per province
edhs <- list()
for(i in names(rp)) {
    edhs[[length(edhs)+1]] <- edhw(edhdf, province=i)
}
names(edhs) <- names(rp)

    The length of edhs is the number of provinces in rp.

    length(edhs)
    [1] 66

    We check for instance the first two entries of Achaia whose cartographical map is produced by funtion plot.map as in the Plotting ancient Roman provinces and regions vignette.

    # start at first province
head(edhs$Ach)
               id tribus                   nomen province_label not_before not_after
4475 HD001917   <NA> Ponponius (= Pomponius)         Achaia       0101      0200
4476 HD001917   <NA>   Ponponia (= Pomponia)         Achaia       0101      0200
4477 HD001917   <NA>                    <NA>         Achaia       0101      0200
4928 HD002097   <NA>                    <NA>         Achaia       0395      0397
4929 HD002097   <NA>                    <NA>         Achaia       0395      0397
4930 HD002097   <NA>                    <NA>         Achaia       0395      0397

    Roman province of Achaia (117 AD).

    Cleaning EDH nomen

    Inscriptions in some provinces were written using Greek characters and, due to encoding and decoding steps in the retrieving of the data (perhaps only specific to MS Windows?), Greek characters are not writen properly with get.edh().

    For instance, we record from edhs the last 50 available nomen entries of Achaia in object Ach, and a second step discards the not available information.

    # last 50 available entries in Achaia
Ach <- tail(edhs$Ach$nomen, 50)
Ach <- Ach[!is.na(Ach)]
     [1] "Ã<U+009C>ÃÂ±Ã\201ÃÂºÃ¡Â½Â·ÃÂ»ÃÂ¹ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0082>"             "Ã¡Â¼Â¸ÃÂ¿Ã¡Â½Â»ÃÂ»ÃÂ¹ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0082>+"                     
 [3] "Ã<U+0091>Ã¡Â½\220Ã<U+0084>Ã\201Ã¡Â½Â½ÃÂ½ÃÂ¹ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0082>"     "ÃÂ¦ÃÂ¿Ã¡Â½Â»ÃÂ»ÃÂ²ÃÂ¹ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0082>+"                    
 [5] "Ã<U+0093>Ã¡Â½Â±ÃÂ»ÃÂ»ÃÂ¹ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0082>"                 "Ã¡Â¼<U+0088>ÃÂ½Ã<U+0087>Ã¡Â½Â±Ã\201ÃÂ¹ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0082>"      
 [7] "[---]"                                         "Ã<U+009A>ÃÂ»ÃÂ±Ã¡Â½Â»ÃÂ´ÃÂ¹ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0082>+*"            
 [9] "Ã<U+009A>ÃÂ»ÃÂ±Ã¡Â½Â»ÃÂ´ÃÂ¹ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0082>"               "Ã<U+009A>ÃÂ»ÃÂ±Ã¡Â½Â»ÃÂ´ÃÂ¹ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0082>"

[15] "ÃÂ¦ÃÂ»Ã¡Â½Â±ÃÂ²ÃÂ¹ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0082>*"                       "Ã<U+009A>ÃÂ»ÃÂ±Ã¡Â½Â»ÃÂ´ÃÂ¹ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0082>"              
[17] "Ã<U+009A>ÃÂ»ÃÂ±Ã¡Â½Â»ÃÂ´ÃÂ¹ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0082>"               "Ã<U+009F>Ã¡Â½\220Ã¡Â½Â±Ã\201ÃÂ¹ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0082>+"

    ğŸ˜•

    As we can see, these entries in Ach have a mixture of Latin extended characters and unicode code points. cln() (that stands for â€œcleaningâ€) is a sdam function that allows reverting encoding corruption process of Greek texts that we saw in the nomen entries of edhs.

    # clean encoding
cln(Ach)

    Which produces these nomen with Greek characters:

    ÎœÎ±ÏÎºá½·Î»Î¹Î¿Ï‚

    Î“á½±Î»Î»Î¹Î¿Ï‚
    á¼ˆÎ½Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î¿Ï‚
    [â€”]
    ÎšÎ»Î±á½»Î´Î¹Î¿Ï‚+
    ÎšÎ»Î±á½»Î´Î¹Î¿Ï‚
    ÎšÎ»Î±á½»Î´Î¹Î¿Ï‚

    ğŸ˜„

    * By default, function cln() removes question marks from the input text, unless the level argument is set to 0. It is also possible to raise the cleaning level of the function for other characters in the input such as * and +. Also note that in the R console output asterisks are kept when handling with Greek text (and the above omisions may be due to a knitr (or rmarkdown) issue.

    Nomen in Aegyptus

    Similarly to Ach, entries in Aegyptus can be cleaned with cln().

    Roman province of Aegyptus (117 AD).

    In the following cases from Aegyptus, the entries have both Greek and Latin characters.

    # record available nomen variable for Aegyptus
Aeg <- edhs$Aeg$nomen
Aeg <- Aeg[!is.na(Aeg)]
    # last five entries
tail(Aeg, 5)
    [1] "Caesar / Ã<U+009A>ÃÂ±Ã¡Â¿<U+0096>Ã<U+0083>ÃÂ±Ã\201"      
[2] "Iulius / Ã¡Â¼Â¸ÃÂ¿Ã¡Â½Â»ÃÂ»ÃÂ¹ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0082>"                 
[3] "Sulpicius* / ÃÂ£ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0085>ÃÂ»Ã<U+0080>Ã¡Â½Â·ÃÂºÃÂ¹ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0082>"
[4] "Septimius / ÃÂ£ÃÂµÃ<U+0080>Ã<U+0084>Ã¡Â½Â·ÃÂ¼ÃÂ¹ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0082>"
[5] "Ã¡Â¼<U+008C>ÃÂ½ÃÂ½ÃÂ¹ÃÂ¿Ã<U+0082> / Annius"             
    # Greek characters in Aegyptus
cln(tail(Aeg, 5))
